APRIL 26, 1985

It is, without a doubt, the
biggest event to hit Homewood
all year.
"It" is Spring Fair, a threeday bash meant both to show
off Hopkins and to give
students and faculty a vacation.
For this year's edition—A
Touch of the Tropics—the
campus was decked out with
palm trees and pink flamingoes, all designed to get
everyone in a tropical mood.
As always, Spring Fair was a
shopper's dream, overflowing
with arts and crafts: everything
from stained glass ornaments to
bean bags for dogs to handmade sweaters.
There was also plenty of
food, although, as in the past
few years, if you wanted a beer
you were confined to the president's garden.
And although Spring Fair '85
lacked
two
traditional
segments—a major concert and
a 10,000 meter run—it featured
one brand new activity: Spring
Fair Games. Consisting of
three-legged races and a tug-ofwar, the games were designed
to provide students with greater
involvment.
Student organized and
directed, Spring Fair is, to say
the least, a major undertaking.
In three days, more than
- 100,000 people stream onto
campus, all hoping to celebrate
the arrival of spring.

Well, it was almost perfect.
When this year's Spring Fair
kicked off at noon last Friday,
the opening ceremonies were
almost flawless.
The weather was perfect: 95
degrees, sunny—a beautiful
day to celebrate the coming of
spring,
The crowd was large—
milling around waiting for a
three-day orgy of food, music,
beer sand sun.
The balloon ascension came
off well, with all the little kids
waiting until just the right moment to loft the balloons into
the cloudless heavens,
Sally Thorner was wonderful
as the emcee, charming and
delightful as always.
There was only one problem:
except for a few people standing near the stage, no one
could hear her.
Throughout the short

ceremony,
Thorner's
microphone kept blipping in
and out, rendering her
unintelligible to most of the
crowd.
For those who didn't hear,
Thorner said that the Fair is a
"wonderful weekend," and
welcomed the crowd "on
behalf of Johns Hopkins, the
Mayor's office and channel 2."
"The release of these
balloons," Thorner continued,
"also symbolizes the release of
Johns Hopkins students and
faculty for the summer."
She then counted to three,
and the hundreds of smiling,
bright-eyed local school
children participating let go of
their balloons to officially open
the Fair.

to have more than balloons in

"humanitarian" aid did allow

remarks on the next appropriations for Nicaraguan contras,
Cranston took up the central
topic of his lecture which concerned the consequences of the
U.S.-Soviet arms race and
several proposals for its
termination.
Cranston began by saying,
"We are currently engaged in
the most dangerous arms race
ever known, and the dangers
will increase as more weapons
get built up on each side. I
don't believe either the U.S. or
the Soviet Union would ever
deliberately launch a nuclear attack. I think the real danger is
an accident or a sudden escalation in tensions that could lead
to
misperceptions
and

likely."
He added, "Despite the
danger, we and the Soviets continue to build up our stockpiles.
Nations are now lining up as if
they were lining up before the
ovens of Auschwitz while the
ovens were made more
efficient."
As a first step towards
avoiding the possibility of a

nuclear
confrontation,
Cranston suggested that the
United States take the initiative
by declaring an immediate halt
to the testing and development
of nuclear weapons and request
the Soviets do the same. He
said of such an initiative, "It

present technology; I don't

"Until we make an honest attempt, we'll never know if the
Soviets are serious about reducing the arms race. We can't
know if they are since we've
never really tried."
He added, "It's absolutely irresponsible for us to allow the
threat of nuclear war to hang
over the heads of our children,
and presently, we're just not on
the right course for doing
anything about it."
Cranston conluded, "We
definitely must take advantage
of the new Soviet leadership.
But I fear it is not likely that we
will break through till we have
a new leader in the White
House."

A Letter From the Editor
To the Reader:
This week, I'd like to step down from
the pedestal of editorial address and use
this space to speak as a graduating
senior. I feel this way I'll be able to speak
a little more candidly about Hopkins and
express my opinions as my own.
The Johns Hopkins University is an
incredibly strange place which seems to
approach undergraduate education in a
unique manner. That is, there is a
definite concentration upon research
above all else. This seems to result in little or no attention to teaching for its own
sake and in an academic intensity which
seems to pervade all aspects of
Homewood life. In addition, there is an
admittedly limited social life here. The
character of the school has changed little during its existence and probably will
not change substantially in the future.
There are advantages and disadvantages in all of this. The advantages are
sometimes difficult to see through all the
garbage, but they do exist. Many
students come here primarily to prepare
for and get into professional schools.
Hopkins is highly successful in this
respect; students can and do get into
graduate schools without a great deal of
difficulty. The lack of a structured social
environment, while annoying to some,
removes the pressure of social activity
found at many colleges and allows
undergraduates to build a social life
which suits them, even if they have to
work at it. As far as the non-existent
teaching standards go, students here are
not taught anything—they have to learn
it. Perhaps that isn't such an awful
situation.
Along with other quirks at Hopkins is
a peculiar approach to student activities
by the students, of all people. An opportunity exists here to become involved in
practically any area which strikes your
fancy. There are very few schools in the
country academically comparable to
Hopkins in which an individual can step
onto a varsity team, write for the school
paper or magazine, chair a Student
Council committee, or create an entirely new organization merely by expressing an interest in doing so. However, only a painfully small number of people
here look beyond their studies and
devote themselves to something extracurricular. This is unfortunate.
Now that I've shared my philosophy
of Hopkins, I'd like to speak a little more
specifically about the News-Letter itself.

by Richard Pan
Labeling proteins with
electron-dense molecules is a
valuable technique for studying
proteins in a transmission electron microscope (TEM). Proteins are composed primarily of
low atomic mass atoms such as
carbon, oxygen, hydrogen, and
nitrogen. These atoms do not
reflect the electron beam well,
thus very high electron energies
are required to study the protein in detail. However, at high
energies, the electron beam
begins to destroy the protein
studied. This destruction
creates broken pieces of the
molecule of artifacts and makes
it difficult to determine whether
you are looking at an artifact or

the protein. By using an
electron-dense label, a lower
energy beam can be used since
the label easily reflects the electrons and can indicate the position of a particular part of the
protein.
The electron-dense label
must have three primary
characteristics. First, the label
must have some chemical structure or functional group that
allows it to be attached at the
desired position of the protein.
Second, it must be sufficiently
electron-dense so that individual molecules can be seen
easily in the TEM. Finally, it
should be small enough to provide sufficient detail or
resolution.
As an example, one com-

The Johns Hopkins
Hospital and School of
Medicine have developed a
program that could become
the new national model for
reversing medicine's historic
failure to diagnose alcoholism
early enough for successful
treatment.
Hopkins will launch the
alcoholism program April 27
with a seminar for some of the
Hospital's and School's
leading medical educators.
Because of Hopkins' leadership in training young physicians, the program's success
promises to change dramatically the way doctors treat the
estimated 20 million alcoholics in the United States.
"Hopkins' new program is
preferable to all previous attempts to improve medical
education regarding alcoholism," says Robert Niven,
M.D., director of the U.S.
National Institute on Alcohol
and Alcoholism in Rockville,
Maryland. Niven labeled the
program "unique" in the
country.
Alcoholism is the primary
cause of 30 to 55 percent of all
admissions to inner city
teaching hospitals, according
to approximately 50 major
studies. But physicians at
rarely
hospitals
these
recognize alcoholism as the
cause of their patients' problems. At Hopkins, for instance, alcoholism is recorded
as the primary diagnosis in
fewer than five percent of

admissions.
is
When alcoholism
diagnosed, the disease often
has progressed to the point
where treatment is difficult, if
not impossible. But in the early stages of the disease, longterm success rates as high as
75 percent are not uncommon, says Emma Stokes,
Ph.D., coordinator of the new
program.
Past programs throughout
the nation have had limitec
impact because they general
ly involved alcholism specia,
ists who taught medical
students about the subject. A
physician's skills, however,
are almost exclusively
during
developed
postgraduate training. The
alcoholism specialists have
tended to remain isolated
from the mainstream of
academic medicine.
In contrast, the April 27
seminar is designed to enlist
the support and participation
of key teachers from seven
clinical departments at
Hopkins. These leading physicians will learn how to
recognize the early stages of
alcoholism, how to plan treatment, how to motivate patients to comply with treatment and how to teach their
students to do the same.
"It's been a Catch 22,"
says Stokes. "These leading
teachers and role models probably never learned how to
diagnose and treat alcoholism
themselves, so they never

taught their students and
associates how to do so."
Stokes, who came to
Hopkins with many years of
experience
developing
alcoholism programs for the
Massachusetts Department of
Public Health, says the new
program also will expand
treatment of and research on
alcoholism.

Musical Showcase Results
by Paul Brunetta
Musical Showcase '85:
Hopkins' Best—a musical
talent show—debuted last
Thursday, April 11, in Shriver
Hall. It was a tremendous success, with attendance estimated
at approximately 450 people.
The show, organized by senior
Paul Brunetta and a small committee, featured 12 performances in the categories of
rock, pop, and classical music,
and musical comedy.
The Tau Babies provided an
excellent rock finale, while
"The Supremes" offered
musical comedy relief. Pop performers included The Hopkins
Hormones, Angela Tang, Pat-

ty Prasada-Rao, Ed Wing, and
Andrew Moffit. Classical pieces
were performed by Melissa Wu,
Andrew Moffit, Dongwoo
Chang, Adlai Waksman and
Howard Greenberg, AnneMarie Ulrich, and an original
composition played by Andy
Piacsek and Becky Bjornson.
Overall the talent was superb
and the audience was extremely receptive and appreciative.
Contestants were judged by
senior housemaster Gillian
Clark and Associate Dean
Jared Cohon. The Tau Babies
and "The Supremes" took the
rock and musical comedy
categories, respectively. Melissa
Wu was judged most talented
performer in the classical music

category, and the Hopkins
Hormones received first place
in the pop category. Freshman
Andrew Moffit was deemed the
overall most talented performer
for his skill on guitar, piano,
and vocals.
Students interested in
organizing the talent show next
year must see Activities Coordinator Tracey Lyon in the Office of Residential Life, which,
along with the HOP, cosponsored this event. The
names of those judged best in
each category will be inscribed
on a plaque ordered for this occasion as an attempt to make
this special endeavor a yearly
event.

It was another big week for
Hopkins baseball as the Blue
Jays won five of their six
games.
Going into the weekend, the
team's record stood at 23-8
overall and 4-2 in conference
play. With nine regular season
games still remaining, the Jays
have already set a school record
for wins, and they may be
headed for a rare trip to the
NCAA Division III playoffs.
Burns blast gives Jays win

On Wednesday, Hopkins
had to go into extra innings to
defeat Salisbury State, 7-4, at
home on a 3-run home run by
junior Scott Burns. The Tigers
broke a 3-3 tie with a run in the
top of the tenth before Hopkins
rallied to tie it up at four as Len
Guarna singled Willie Raedle
home from second base.
Salisbury State then changed
pitchers, and Coach Robert
Babb responded by inserting
Jon Meltzer in to pinch hit. The
move almost proved golden as
Meltzer smashed a ball to the
fence, but it curved foul. The
sophomore worked it to a 3-2
count before grounding out to
second base. Guarna moved to
second on the play. The visitors
then intentionally walked Tom
Finegan, bringing Burns to the
plate.
On the fourth pitch, Burns
smashed the ball high, long and
over the fence in left for the
game winner.
"It was a fastball up and in,"
said Burns. "As I watched it
go, I was just hoping the fielder
wouldn't catch it." Pete Blohm
picked up the win in relief to
improve his record to 6-0.
Burns's hit may have given
the Jays their most important
victory of the season to date.
According to co-captain Craig
Brooks, the game was key for
two major reasons. "For one
thing, the team was down after
getting knocked out from the
MAC playoffs (Swarthmore
by

State is a tough team that's

NCAA tourney bid sought

To make the NCAA's,teams
get bids by region. The committee looks at a number of factors
when making its selections, including win-loss record,
strength of schedule, batting
average, and earned run
average. Though Hopkins is
strong in all of these categories,
Brooks feels that "it may take
a 30-10 record to get us there."
On Sunday, Hopkins split a
double-header at York College.
In the opener, Geoff Bender
tossed a two-hit shutout to lead
the Blue to a 5-0 win. Bender
struck out eight and walked only one as he raised his record to
5-2 and lowered his ERA to
2.76.
Sophomore catcher Mike
Goudy was the lone Jay batter
to have a big day as he was a
perfect 3 for 3.
In the nightcap, York was
limited to two hits, once again,
by Mark Campbell, but the
hosts took advantage of five
Hopkins errors and some
strong pitching to prevail 4-1.
Jays bite the bullet

Saturday saw Hopkins sweep
two from Gettysburg College at
home by identical scores of 8-5.
In Game 1, the Jays managed just five hits, but they reached base ten times on walks and
parlayed this into the eight

whole way and, though he
wasn't his usual dominant self,
only allowed two earned runs in
picking up the win. Hopkins
broke a 5-5 deadlock in the bottom of the sixth with three
runs.
Dave Psenicska relieved Jack
Flynn in the fifth inning of the
second game and went the rest
of the way to pick up the win.
Hopkins scored four runs in the
bottom of the inning to build a
7-4 lead they would never relinquish. Flynn and Psenicska
yielded only four hits between
them, but they walked five and
weathered five Blue Jay errors
in giving up just one earned
run.

Senior captain Keni Fischer
and sophomore Kay Nelsen
kept playoff hopes for the
women's tennis team alive
Wednesday in dramatic
fashion.
The two travelled to Dickinson and battled back from a 2-1
deficit to capture the third set
of a number one doubles match
that had been stopped earlier in
the season due to darkness. The
final score of the set, 7-5, gave
Hopkins a 5-4 victory in what
had been a tied conference
match.
Yesterday the entire team
followed with an impressive 7-2
win over Ursinus. This leaves
the Blue Jay's season record at
4-2. Their conference mark of
2-1 has the team in a three way

tie for first place in the
Southeast division of the Middle Atlantic Conference.
Dickinson and Gettysburg also
have one loss apiece.
If Hopkins defeats Elizabethtown this afternoon, play will
begin tomorrow to break the
three-way tie. Hopkins will face
Dickinson here Saturday. The
winner of that match will be at
home Sunday against Gettysburg, which won a flip for
the bye. The winner of that
match will be the champion of
the Southeast division of the
MAC and will face Franklin
and Marshall, the winner of the
Southwest division, Monday
afternoon. The winner of this
match will face the winner of
the North division Wednesday
for the MAC conference
championship.

Starting with yesterday's Ursinus victory, the Blue Jays face
the possibility of playing five
matches in five straight days.
On the other hand, if the team
does not defeat Elizabethtown
this afternoon, they will have
acquired two conference losses
and the season will be over.
Thi.; difficult playoff
schedule is necessitated by a
simple tie-breaker system that
did not work. In head-to-head
competition, the three schools
had won an equal number of
individual matches. Gettysburg
downed Hopkins, Hopkins
beat Dickinson, and Dickinson
defeated Gettysburg by identical 5-4 scores.

by Robert Jackson

Senior captain Keni Fischer
and sophomore Kay Nelsen
kept playoff hopes for the
women's tennis team alive
Wednesday in dramatic
fashion.
The two travelled to Dickinson and battled back from a 2-1
deficit to capture the third set
of a number one doubles match
that had been stopped earlier in
the season due to darkness. The
final score of the set, 7-5, gave
Hopkins a 5-4 victory in what
had been a tied conference
match.
Yesterday the entire team
followed with an impressive 7-2
win over Ursinus. This leaves
the Blue Jay's season record at
4-2. Their conference mark of
2-1 has the team in a three way

tie for first place in the
Southeast division of the Middle Atlantic Conference.
Dickinson and Gettysburg also
have one loss apiece.
If Hopkins defeats Elizabethtown this afternoon, play will
begin tomorrow to break the
three-way tie. Hopkins will face
Dickinson here Saturday. The
winner of that match will be at
home Sunday against Gettysburg, which won a flip for
the bye. The winner of that
match will be the champion of
the Southeast division of the
MAC and will face Franklin
and Marshall, the winner of the
Southwest division, Monday
afternoon. The winner of this
match will face the winner of
the North division Wednesday
for the MAC conference
championship.

Starting with yesterday's Ursinus victory, the Blue Jays face
the possibility of playing five
matches in five straight days.
On the other hand, if the team
does not defeat Elizabethtown
this afternoon, they will have
acquired two conference losses
and the season will be over.
Thi.3 difficult playoff
schedule is necessitated by a
simple tie-breaker system that
did not work. In head-to-head
competition, the three schools
had won an equal number of
individual matches. Gettysburg
downed Hopkins, Hopkins
beat Dickinson, and Dickinson
defeated Gettysburg by identical 5-4 scores.

The lady laxers took victories
in two of their three contests
this past week and brought
their season record to an even
6-6.
Last Thursday the Jays were
led by Co-captains Shelly Davis
and Janice Brill, who combined for five goals as the team
dumped Dickinson, 9-6. The
halftime score of this night contest was 5-5, but the Blue Jay
offense got in gear in the second stanza, and senior Mary
Yun kept the Beavers in check
while posting 13 saves.
Coach Sally Beth Anderson
was very pleased with the victory. "We played a really
strong overall game," she said.
"Mary Yun was consistent in
the goal, and Jennifer O'Connor shadowed their big scorer
out of the game.'
Freshmen Jen Stahl and
Maggie Schmidt, junior Eileen
Janec, and sophomore Margo
McFarland each contributed a
goal to account for the rest of
the Jays' scoring.
The lady taxers fell to a stubborn Swarthmore team 6-5 in a
hard-fought contest this past
Saturday at Homewood. After
being unable to score in the first
half of this contest, the Jays put
five quick goals on the board
after the halftime intermission
to take a 5-4 lead in the contest.
Despite tremendous defensive
play by Ellen rickson and
Vanessa Tatum, the team watched the Garnet score the game
winning goal with only three
minutes left in regulation time.
"They played a tight zone
defense to keep our scoring attack in check for most of the
game," Anderson noted. "It's
frustrating to lose a tight game
like this. We just needed one in
the clutch."
Davis scored two goals, while
McFarland, Stahl, and Schmidt
accounted for single tallies to
round out the team's scoring.
Janec and Schmidt combined for nine goals as the Jays
bombed Lebanon Valley, 18-9
Tuesday. The squad played
"deny defense," as Mary Yun
faced a total of only 14 shots,
and much of the game's action
took place at the Hopkins offensive end of the field.
"I was really impressed with
the scoring explosion in this
game," the coach noted. "I
thought that co-captains Brill
and Davis really played aggressive games."

Corruption Rages Across the Athletic Center
In a move which shocked the
entire Homewood campus and
sent vibrations through the very
walls of the Newton H. White,
Jr. Athletic Center, federal
agents moved in Monday and
arrested Hopkins head basketball coach Ed "Nappy" Doherty and assistant coach Lee
"Happy" Horowitz. Tuesday,
the two were arraigned in
federal court on multiple
charges including point shaving, illegal recruiting, and
corruption.
"I was shocked," said
department secretary Jane
Smoot, who witnessed the arrest by "three men in dark blue
suits." Horowitz, who was
busy adjusting the large
schedule board in his office at
the time, reportedly resisted arrest and had to be subdued by
force. Both he and Doherty
were handcuffed, as they were
described in a federal APB as
being "armed and dangerous."
Doherty especially is known for
sudden and extreme outbursts
of excitement.
According to Justice Department official Nick Nikic, the
arrests were the culmination of
a long investigation involving
corruption in Hopkins basketball. "We have documented
evidence of point shaving of
unprecedented magnitude," he
said in a prepared statement.
"We have also uncovered over
twenty instances of gross
recruiting violations."
When asked to elaborate,
Nikic unloaded a suitcase of
documents and photos. "We
estimate that Doherty and
Horowitz have earned over $2

million in illicit funds from this
operation. Point shaving alone
accounted for approximately
$1.7 million."
Specifically, Nikic cited the
Blue Jays' 82-44 loss to
Widener on February 2 this
year. The betting line favored
Hopkins by 6 points. Doherty,
as alleged by the Justice
purposely
Department,
disrupted the Blue Jay offense
and refused to replace players
in foul trouble, reducing an early Hopkins lead and easily falling below the point spread.
The coaches' take from that
game alone, according to Nikic,
was over $300,000. Half of this
was split by the two, and half
was channeled into a bogus
summer camp which Horowitz
supposedly operates in New
England.
"I can't believe it," said
sophomore power forward
Steve Mitchell. "I thought that
we just got blown away night
after night. I never thought that
shaving was involved."
Despite the Jays' 8-13 record
this season, informed sources
claim that Doherty and
Horowitz were successful by
displaying the Blue Jays' obvious individual talent, thus
swinging the betting line in their
favor. On game nights,
however, the two made sure
that the contest would not
result in a Blue Jay win.
As for the counts of
recruiting, Nikic presented the
testimony of several high school
seniors who claimed that
Doherty offered them bonuses
of "cars and luscious Hopkins
women" in exchange for a

signature on a letter of intent.
"Oh, he said I could have
anything," said Joe Piazza
from the Bronx, New York. "I
was promised booze, cars, and
loose women. When it cane to
Hopkins, however, I found
none of these. The locker room
wasn't even carpeted, and we
were promised a full stereo
system."
Evidently, such illegal
recruiting schemes backfired
when recruits actually came to
Homewood. Though five
freshmen "were almost think-

ing about coming," said junior
captain Ralph Horne, the Jays
played the 1984-85 season
without freshmen.
At a press conference
Wednesday
afternoon,
Hopkins Athletic Director Bob
Scott expressed his support for
the two coaches. "I am fully
assured of the innocence of
Nappy and Happy," he said.
"I want to assure you that there
is no doubt in my mind. I have
total confidence that we will
soon see their names
exonerated."

of mail. In addition to those
epistles of bemusement or
hatred, the occasional plea for
advicefalls across my desk. For

stained with formaldehyde and
tears. Ifeel her words speak to
countless others on this campus, and her dilemma could be
universal.
Dear Sujata,
You don't know me, or
maybe you do but you just ignore me by staring into your
coffee all the time. But you just
have to listen, because I'm on
the edge. My problem is
something I can't admit to easily, in the face of massive peer
contempt. But at a Pre-Meds
Anonymous meeting last night,
I realized the first step toward
recovery is the recognition of
the problem. I don't want to
recover, exactly, but I need
help. Or rather he does. You
see, lam guilty ofloving a premed.
Oh, I never meant to in the
first place. My mother warned
me about the kind of boys who
would try to get under your
sweater with a stethoscope. But
when I met Ezekiel all caution

It all started one long-ago
afternoon. As a Writing
Seminars major, I was scouting
D-Level for a Jack Kerouac
novel and someone cute to
write in my poetry journal
about. It was a freak accident
meeting Zeke, as he likes to be
calledfor short; tall, dark, and
squint-eyed and stoopshouldered already. He had the
most adorable stutter I ever
heard. Zeke was in the process
of hiding the reserve room's
biology exams beside some
Sylvia Plath poetry. Hefigured
no pre-med knew the library

Right then Ifellfor him, that

evidence of a far more
sophisticated breed of man
than I was accustomed to. Zeke
saidflat out he didn't have time
for girls. I decided immediately I would become the woman
he needed, the backbone for his
brilliant academic career.
So, I won him. I sat next to
him during 14-hour marathons
in the Hut. I knit him sweaters
to wear on chilly C-Level.

When he finally made it out of
lab tired and hungry at 9:00

laughter and drinking when
Zeke
might
have
a
breakthrough
balancing
chemical equations?
There were hard times mixed in with the good. Some

Med School job and hold me
against his acetone-scented
skin. I nearly died with desire.
But a few minutes later he
would be out the door to the
Hut and I'd be left alone,
caressing the textbooks of his I
lined up on the other side of my
futon. As I passed my hands
over their hard cracked surfaces
I thought longingly of my premed and knew at least he

Sleeping with Zeke was a

kind of shy to talk about this

disrobed and only came back
when I swore I was wearing a
sheet. Then he fell asleep and

something like 'Don't touch my
test tube!' He woke up in a cold
sweat when his beeper went off.
Pulling on his Levis, he was out
the door on call for the First
Aid Squad.
Waiting up nights was always
the worst part. There I was with
countles cups of Sanka praying
my love would return once
again to my side. His commitment to society's well-being
moved me to tears, but I
couldn't help wishing Zeke
would spend a teensy bit more

instantly

A Letter From the Editor
To the Reader:
This week, I'd like to step down from
the pedestal of editorial address and use
this space to speak as a graduating
senior. I feel this way I'll be able to speak
a little more candidly about Hopkins and
express my opinions as my own.
The Johns Hopkins University is an
incredibly strange place which seems to
approach undergraduate education in a
unique manner. That is, there is a
definite concentration upon research
above all else. This seems to result in little or no attention to teaching for its own
sake and in an academic intensity which
seems to pervade all aspects of
Homewood life. In addition, there is an
admittedly limited social life here. The
character of the school has changed little during its existence and probably will
not change substantially in the future.
There are advantages and disadvantages in all of this. The advantages are
sometimes difficult to see through all the
garbage, but they do exist. Many
students come here primarily to prepare
for and get into professional schools.
Hopkins is highly successful in this
respect; students can and do get into
graduate schools without a great deal of
difficulty. The lack of a structured social
environment, while annoying to some,
removes the pressure of social activity
found at many colleges and allows
undergraduates to build a social life
which suits them, even if they have to
work at it. As far as the non-existent
teaching standards go, students here are
not taught anything—they have to learn
it. Perhaps that isn't such an awful
situation.
Along with other quirks at Hopkins is
a peculiar approach to student activities
by the students, of all people. An opportunity exists here to become involved in
practically any area which strikes your
fancy. There are very few schools in the
country academically comparable to
Hopkins in which an individual can step
onto a varsity team, write for the school
paper or magazine, chair a Student
Council committee, or create an entirely new organization merely by expressing an interest in doing so. However, only a painfully small number of people
here look beyond their studies and
devote themselves to something extracurricular. This is unfortunate.
Now that I've shared my philosophy
of Hopkins, I'd like to speak a little more
specifically about the News-Letter itself.

Charles Dickinson has a

this talent which makes Crows
an interesting and enjoyable
work of fiction.
The protagonist of Crows is
Robert Cigar, a young college
graduate who has had a taste
of adult life; and decided that
he did not like it. He is invited
to stay at the home of one of

his professors, and readily accepts. When the professor is
killed in a boating accident,
Robert feels he has an obligation to remain in the house
and comfort the family, even
though they do not agree with
him. He prolongs his stay for
several years, long after his
welcome has elapsed. In his
dealings with the family,
which consists of the widow,
her two sons, and her only
daughter (who Robert sleeps
with), Robert grows and
learns many things about
himself and the world.
The name of the novel
derives from the stories that
Ben, the professor, told to
Robert. Ben instilled in crows
all the characteristics that he
saw in people or wished people had. In his stories, the
crows often symbolize him
and those around him.
Through the stories of crows
we learn much about the man
who tells them and about life
in general. When Ben disappears in a lake and is not
found, Robert continues the
search for his body long after
the authorities give up. In his
never-ending search, Robert
lives in the past, not wanting
to face his life ahead of him.
It is not until he can let go of
the past that he gains the confidence in himself necessary to
continue his life on his own.
All of the relationships in
Crows are well written and
highly emotional. Anyone
who likes reading about people and their interactions will
almost surely enjoy this book.

Labeling proteins with
electron-dense molecules is a
valuable technique for studying
proteins in a transmission electron microscope (TEM). Proteins are composed primarily of
low atomic mass atoms such as
carbon, oxygen, hydrogen, and
nitrogen. These atoms do not
reflect the electron beam well,
thus very high electron energies
are required to study the protein in detail. However, at high
energies, the electron beam
begins to destroy the protein
studied. This destruction
creates broken pieces of the
molecule of artifacts and makes
it difficult to determine whether
you are looking at an artifact or

the protein. By using an
electron-dense label, a lower
energy beam can be used since
the label easily reflects the electrons and can indicate the position of a particular part of the
protein.
The electron-dense label
must have three primary
characteristics. First, the label
must have some chemical structure or functional group that
allows it to be attached at the
desired position of the protein.
Second, it must be sufficiently
electron-dense so that individual molecules can be seen
easily in the TEM. Finally, it
should be small enough to provide sufficient detail or
resolution.
As an example, one com-

The Johns Hopkins
Hospital and School of
Medicine have developed a
program that could become
the new national model for
reversing medicine's historic
failure to diagnose alcoholism
early enough for successful
treatment.
Hopkins will launch the
alcoholism program April 27
with a seminar for some of the
Hospital's and School's
leading medical educators.
Because of Hopkins' leadership in training young physicians, the program's success
promises to change dramatically the way doctors treat the
estimated 20 million alcoholics in the United States.
"Hopkins' new program is
preferable to all previous attempts to improve medical
education regarding alcoholism," says Robert Niven,
M.D., director of the U.S.
National Institute on Alcohol
and Alcoholism in Rockville,
Maryland. Niven labeled the
program "unique" in the
country.
Alcoholism is the primary
cause of 30 to 55 percent of all
admissions to inner city
teaching hospitals, according
to approximately 50 major
studies. But physicians at
rarely
hospitals
these
recognize alcoholism as the
cause of their patients' problems. At Hopkins, for instance, alcoholism is recorded
as the primary diagnosis in
fewer than five percent of

admissions.
is
When alcoholism
diagnosed, the disease often
has progressed to the point
where treatment is difficult, if
not impossible. But in the early stages of the disease, longterm success rates as high as
75 percent are not uncommon, says Emma Stokes,
Ph.D., coordinator of the new
program.
Past programs throughout
the nation have had limitec
impact because they general
ly involved alcholism specia,
ists who taught medical
students about the subject. A
physician's skills, however,
are almost exclusively
during
developed
postgraduate training. The
alcoholism specialists have
tended to remain isolated
from the mainstream of
academic medicine.
In contrast, the April 27
seminar is designed to enlist
the support and participation
of key teachers from seven
clinical departments at
Hopkins. These leading physicians will learn how to
recognize the early stages of
alcoholism, how to plan treatment, how to motivate patients to comply with treatment and how to teach their
students to do the same.
"It's been a Catch 22,"
says Stokes. "These leading
teachers and role models probably never learned how to
diagnose and treat alcoholism
themselves, so they never

taught their students and
associates how to do so."
Stokes, who came to
Hopkins with many years of
experience
developing
alcoholism programs for the

Public Health, says the new
program also will expand
treatment of and research on
alcoholism.

played his more recent ballady,
poppy songs, and at his best
when he went for the straight
Blues numbers. Still I have problems with a contented, rich old
man playing the Blues—maybe
it should be said that he plays
in the "Blues Style."
Backing Clapton up was a
rather competent unit—drums,
keyboard, rhythm guitar, bass,
and two female back-up
singers. The bass player, who
looked exactly like Kurt Vonnegut, seemed even more bored
than Clapton (no easy feat) and
a few times played with a
cigarette between his fingers.
The two backing singers each
got a turn to pretend to be Janis
Joplin and both times gave me
a headache with their
"hysterics."
All in all, however, it was a
rather entertaining show—
certainly not awe-inspiring or
anything like that. And I emphasize "show." I have no problems seeing Clapton in Las
Vegas in a decade or so. The
way it was, a good portion of
the audience was pushing thirty, the girls and especially the
bass player already had that
"showbiz" style, and a few
times the light show was tacky
enough (simulating rain while
he's singing "Let it Rain") to
belong to Vegas. The crowd
generally went crazy when it
recognized the opening chords

of a classic old song and left to
get refreshments when he
played something newer. A
nostalgia show.
Graham Parker, who opened, playing with his new backup "The Shot," should've
played a nostalgia show but
didn't get a chance. In fact he
didn't get to put on much of a
show at all, only playing for a
half an hour or so. Most of his
set consisted of songs off his
new album, Steady Nerves, an
album that has been hailed as
a comeback but which to my
ears sounds more trite and commercial than anything he's ever
done. Though the newer songs
did come off sounding much
better than they did on vinyl, as
with Clapton the highlights
were the older songs. With the
opening chords of Squeezing
Out Spark's.-"Local Girls" I
was struck with an incredible
sense of nostalgia (yearning for
high school already?). The
Beach Boys and even Clapton
at his height were before my
time, but Graham Parker was
it. I wanted to hear all the
classics—"Protection,"
"Stupefaction," "Mercury
Poisoning," that I lived
through, but he didn't have
time to play them. I don't know
about Clapton but in ten years
when Graham Parker is playing
Atlantic City, I'm going to be
there.

It was another big week for
Hopkins baseball as the Blue
Jays won five of their six
games.
Going into the weekend, the
team's record stood at 23-8
overall and 4-2 in conference
play. With nine regular season
games still remaining, the Jays
have already set a school record

headed for a rare trip to the
NCAA Division III playoffs.
Burns blast gives Jays win

On Wednesday, Hopkins
had to go into extra innings to
defeat Salisbury State, 7-4, at
home on a 3-run home run by
junior Scott Burns. The Tigers
broke a 3-3 tie with a run in the
top of the tenth before Hopkins
rallied to tie it up at four as Len
Guarna singled Willie Raedle
home from second base.
Salisbury State then changed
pitchers, and Coach Robert
Babb responded by inserting
Jon Meltzer in to pinch hit. The
move almost proved golden as
Meltzer smashed a ball to the
fence, but it curved foul. The
sophomore worked it to a 3-2
count before grounding out to
second base. Guarna moved to
second on the play. The visitors
then intentionally walked Tom
Finegan, bringing Burns to the
plate.
On the fourth pitch, Burns
smashed the ball high, long and
over the fence in left for the
game winner.
"It was a fastball up and in,"
said Burns. "As I watched it
go, I was just hoping the fielder
wouldn't catch it." Pete Blohm
picked up the win in relief to
improve his record to 6-0.
Burns's hit may have given
the Jays their most important
victory of the season to date.
According to co-captain Craig
Brooks, the game was key for
two major reasons. "For one
thing, the team was down after
getting knocked out from the
MAC playoffs (Swarthmore

a 30-10 record to get us there."
On Sunday, Hopkins split a
double-header at York College.

5-2 and lowered his ERA to

Sophomore catcher Mike

to have a big day as he was a

by Mark Campbell, but the
hosts took advantage of five
Hopkins errors and some
strong pitching to prevail 4-1.

Hopkins a 5-4 victory in what

match.
Yesterday the entire team
followed with an impressive 7-2
win over Ursinus. This leaves
the Blue Jay's season record at
4-2. Their conference mark of
2-1 has the team in a three way

tie for first place in the
Southeast division of the Middle Atlantic Conference.
Dickinson and Gettysburg also
have one loss apiece.
If Hopkins defeats Elizabethtown this afternoon, play will
begin tomorrow to break the
three-way tie. Hopkins will face
Dickinson here Saturday. The
winner of that match will be at
home Sunday against Gettysburg, which won a flip for
the bye. The winner of that
match will be the champion of
the Southeast division of the
MAC and will face Franklin
and Marshall, the winner of the
Southwest division, Monday
afternoon. The winner of this
match will face the winner of
the North division Wednesday
for the MAC conference
championship.

Starting with yesterday's Ursinus victory, the Blue Jays face
the possibility of playing five
matches in five straight days.
On the other hand, if the team
does not defeat Elizabethtown
this afternoon, they will have
acquired two conference losses
and the season will be over.
Thi.; difficult playoff
schedule is necessitated by a
simple tie-breaker system that
did not work. In head-to-head
competition, the three schools
had won an equal number of
individual matches. Gettysburg
downed Hopkins, Hopkins
beat Dickinson, and Dickinson
defeated Gettysburg by identical 5-4 scores.

The lady laxers took victories

five quick goals on the board

minutes left in regulation time.

defense to keep our scoring attack in check for most of the

frustrating to lose a tight game
like this. We just needed one in
the clutch."

bombed Lebanon Valley, 18-9

"deny defense," as Mary Yun
faced a total of only 14 shots,
and much of the game's action
took place at the Hopkins offensive end of the field.

the scoring explosion in this
game," the coach noted. "I
thought that co-captains Brill
and Davis really played aggressive games."

Corruption Rages Across the Athletic Center
In a move which shocked the
entire Homewood campus and
sent vibrations through the very
walls of the Newton H. White,
Jr. Athletic Center, federal
agents moved in Monday and
arrested Hopkins head basketball coach Ed "Nappy" Doherty and assistant coach Lee
"Happy" Horowitz. Tuesday,
the two were arraigned in
federal court on multiple
charges including point shaving, illegal recruiting, and
corruption.
"I was shocked," said
department secretary Jane
Smoot, who witnessed the arrest by "three men in dark blue
suits." Horowitz, who was
busy adjusting the large
schedule board in his office at
the time, reportedly resisted arrest and had to be subdued by
force. Both he and Doherty
were handcuffed, as they were
described in a federal APB as
being "armed and dangerous."
Doherty especially is known for
sudden and extreme outbursts
of excitement.
According to Justice Department official Nick Nikic, the
arrests were the culmination of
a long investigation involving
corruption in Hopkins basketball. "We have documented
evidence of point shaving of
unprecedented magnitude," he
said in a prepared statement.
"We have also uncovered over
twenty instances of gross
recruiting violations."
When asked to elaborate,
Nikic unloaded a suitcase of
documents and photos. "We
estimate that Doherty and
Horowitz have earned over $2

million in illicit funds from this
operation. Point shaving alone
accounted for approximately
$1.7 million."
Specifically, Nikic cited the
Blue Jays' 82-44 loss to
Widener on February 2 this
year. The betting line favored
Hopkins by 6 points. Doherty,
as alleged by the Justice
purposely
Department,
disrupted the Blue Jay offense
and refused to replace players
in foul trouble, reducing an early Hopkins lead and easily falling below the point spread.
The coaches' take from that
game alone, according to Nikic,
was over $300,000. Half of this
was split by the two, and half
was channeled into a bogus
summer camp which Horowitz
supposedly operates in New
England.
"I can't believe it," said
sophomore power forward
Steve Mitchell. "I thought that
we just got blown away night
after night. I never thought that
shaving was involved."
Despite the Jays' 8-13 record
this season, informed sources
claim that Doherty and
Horowitz were successful by
displaying the Blue Jays' obvious individual talent, thus
swinging the betting line in their
favor. On game nights,
however, the two made sure
that the contest would not
result in a Blue Jay win.
As for the counts of
recruiting, Nikic presented the
testimony of several high school
seniors who claimed that
Doherty offered them bonuses
of "cars and luscious Hopkins
women" in exchange for a

signature on a letter of intent.
"Oh, he said I could have
anything," said Joe Piazza
from the Bronx, New York. "I
was promised booze, cars, and
loose women. When it cane to
Hopkins, however, I found
none of these. The locker room
wasn't even carpeted, and we
were promised a full stereo
system."
Evidently, such illegal
recruiting schemes backfired
when recruits actually came to
Homewood. Though five
freshmen "were almost think-

ing about coming," said junior
captain Ralph Horne, the Jays
played the 1984-85 season
without freshmen.
At a press conference
Wednesday
afternoon,
Hopkins Athletic Director Bob
Scott expressed his support for
the two coaches. "I am fully
assured of the innocence of
Nappy and Happy," he said.
"I want to assure you that there
is no doubt in my mind. I have
total confidence that we will
soon see their names
exonerated."

"Maybe selling buttered
toast at Spring Fair wasn't such
a good idea after all," said a
downcast Queen Momo
Patricia Vale Merrick at the
final Alpha Momo Squid
meeting last week. The disappointing truth for the Momos
is that finally, despite all fundraising efforts, they will have to
give up their dreams of flying
to Seattle, Washington, to visit
their founder, Joanne Wittau,
who deserted Baltimore and the
'mos back in the spring of 1982.
In spite of this gloomy
forecast, the AMS Sorority,
Inc., was able to come to some
cheery conclusions at their
meeting. The proposal to adopt
fuchsia as the official sorority
color, raised by Minister of
Propaganda Eileen Fitzgerald,

O'Connor, Minister of Torture

around to all the dorms and introduce herself to all the guys

shortage seem to bother Jessie
Chai, Minister of Athletics,
who had to go play squash. Incidentally, Chai also led the

Hopkins career, with a total of

south, thus ending the last
Alpha Miomo Squid meeting as
they were known to Baltimore
and the Homewood campus.

him. I loped alongside as he

Run, begging him to remember
all the good times. The time I
ran his experiments so he could
bone up for the Calc III exam.
The time I drove him to the
MCAT's at 4:00 a.m. so he
could sit outside the building
and get in the mood. All the
times I wrote CAL poems for
him.

I finally got him back when
I dropped to my knees in the
middle of Levering. "Zeke," I
cried, "I'm dying. You can't
leave me."
instantly
was
Zeke
fascinated. With my amazing
lack of symptoms, he was sure
I had a strange new disease.
With close research, he could
write a paper which would get
him in the Flex-Med program.
He started to treat me with
respect. As for myself, I was
just glad to have him finally
play doctor with me. I was in
heaven.
My problem is this. Zeke has
med school interviews this fall.
Of course, this is the most important moment in our lives.
Zeke's hard work has paid off
and a brilliant future full of station wagons, Chippendale furniture and home computers
waits in the wings.
The tragedy is Zeke can't
really sit through these interviews. Something I forgot to
mention earlier is his phobia.
He has a real dread of people
in business suits, especially if
they wear gold tie pins. Matching cufflinks have him on the
floor. Zeke can function
perfectly in his day-to-day
world since all the grownups
down at the Lab wear white
coats. I've seen him get queasy
when Steve Muller shook his
hand, so I know he will be in
trouble with a situation as formal as the Med School Interview. What can we do? He's
flying up to Harvard
in one week! Whatever you say,
don't bother to suggest dropping Zeke. Although I know he
is bad news, I can't stop loving
that man.
Desperately Yours,
Deirdre X.

There must be a few people
out there who could help Deirdre more than a trite and tacky
yellow journalist can. We all
know pre-meds; some of them
are our best friends, the kind
who add for us in Eddie's
check-out lane. What is a med
school interview really like? Is
there a way to transcend tiepins? Get your Rx to the
gatehouse by 5:00 p.m. Tuesday. Two lives hang in the
balance.

Turn To Speak Out.
